content:
I’ve always been deeply curious about technology, and over the years, my interest has blossomed into a full-fledged passion. During my undergraduate and graduate studies in History, I had the opportunity to delve into the world of Digital History, which introduced me to Linux and the open-source community. Witnessing the profound impact of technology on our lives fueled my intrigue even further.
In 2018, I made the complete switch to Linux, a decision I have never regretted! Through my Linux journey, I have acquired invaluable lessons, the most important being that there is no problem without a solution. In 2022, I embarked on my journey in Web Development at PUC Minas, diligently honing my skills in HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React, React Native, MySQL, C#, .NET, ASP.NET Core, and MongoDB. Additionally, I have been actively pursuing self-study in various technologies that have piqued my interest, such as Rust, Vue.js, Docker, and Kubernetes.
Skills # Development HTML - CSS | Bootstrap | Sass | Tailwind JavaScript | React.js | Node.js | React Native C# | .NET | ASP.NET Core | MVC SQL | MySQL | SQLServer | SQLite NoSQL | MongoDB Git | Github | Gitlab | Bitbucket AI | Llama | Gemini Python Rust Linux Shell Scripting Ubuntu Debian NixOS Arch Linux WSL Docker Design Figma Photoshop Penpot Data Microsoft Power BI GNU PSPP Google Looker Studio Education # School Link Degree Date
summary: I’ve always been deeply curious about technology, and over the years, my interest has blossomed into a full-fledged passion.
title: About

content:
ORCID Lattes ResearchGate Google Scholar Dissertation (Master’s/UFJF) # (De)constructing History on the Internet: Views on the Brazilian Military Dictatorship in channels of the “new right” on YouTube (2013-2018)
Abstract: This dissertation aims to analyze videos from major channels of the Brazilian new right on YouTube that address the theme of the Brazilian military dictatorship, as well as their respective comments. We will work with the time frame from June 2013 to the year 2018, because the June demonstrations created a favorable ground for the diffusion of “liberal in economy and conservative in customs” ideas from the new right, which coincides precisely with their more active appearance in the public and digital sphere. From this, we will seek to understand how these subjects interpret, discuss, and share the past, as well as to identify the inconsistencies of the defended contents, in order to problematize their revisionist and denialist views on the dictatorship, in contrast to what is consolidated in Brazilian historiography on the subject. This study allows us to reflect on the role of the historian in the face of new media, considering its great power to reach the public, and the challenges posed by the disputes that occur in the public sphere regarding the memories of the Brazilian military dictatorship.
Monograph (Bachelor’s/UFJF) # The Stories They Tell: The Brazilian Military Dictatorship Through the Eyes of Three Conservative YouTube Channels
Monograph (Teaching Degree/UFJF) # Denialism of the Military Dictatorship in the Classroom: Between Memory and History
Publications # Journals: # The “New Right” on YouTube: Conservatism and Historical Denialism about the Brazilian Military Dictatorship
Nature and Culture: From Rejection to (Re)construction - with Janaína Di Lourenço Esteves
Conference proceedings: # Conservatism on YouTube and the Brazilian Military Dictatorship
So Happy (We Never Were): The Memory of the Armed Struggle in the Brazilian Military Dictatorship from the film “We Were Never So Happy” (1984, Murilo Salles)
Memory, History, and Cinema: Miguel Littín - The Clandestine Filmmaker in 1985 Chile
Event management # XXXIV History Week of UFJF - Gender, race, sexuality, and class: intersectional potentialities from the historical perspective - (2018) Formatting and standardization of event conference proceedings
II Internal Meeting of UFJF History: 30 years of the Federal Constitution and the directions of democracy in Brazil - (2018) XXXIII History Week of UFJF - Brazilian artistic representations: from the Second Reign to the Vargas Era - (2017) XXXII History Week of UFJF - The Social Role of the Historian: Contemporary Challenges for Writing History - (2016)
summary: ORCID Lattes ResearchGate Google Scholar Dissertation (Master’s/UFJF) # (De)constructing History on the Internet: Views on the Brazilian Military Dictatorship in channels of the “new right” on YouTube (2013-2018)

content:
This is a list of the best free and open source software alternatives for security and privacy. The list is divided into categories and subcategories. The software is listed alphabetically within each category. The list includes software for all major operating systems (Windows, macOS, Linux, Android, iOS) and is updated regularly. Sometimes there are also Not Open Source (NOS) software, but they are indicated as such (Beeing NOS does not mean that the software is bad, but it is recommended for security and/or privacy reasons).
Feel free to contribute to the list!
NOS = Not Open Source
Ref = Refer a friend, affiliate link
Authenticators # AndOPT - Android Authy - NOS Bitwarden - Paid version Ente Auth FreeOPT Proton Pass - Paid version Browsers # Brave DuckDuckGo Firefox Floorp LibreWolf Mullvad Browser Tor Calendar # Etar Gnome Calendar Kalendar Lightning Calendar Mailbox Nextcloud Calendar Posteo Proton Calendar Tuta - Ref Cloud and Sync # Cryptomator Filen Mega - Ref - NOS Nextcloud Owncloud pCloud - NOS Syncthing Code Editors # Atom - Discontinued CodeSandbox Cosmic - TBA Eclipse IDE Expo.dev Kate Neovim Pulsar - Atom Fork PyCharm Vim VSCodium Digital Audio Workstation # Ardour Audacity LMMS Tenacity E-mails # Mailbox Posteo ProtonMail RiseUp Tuta - Ref Image editors # GIMP Inkscape Krita PhotoGIMP Maps # OsmAnd - iOS / Android OpenStreetMap Media Servers # Jellyfin Kodi Stremio Universal Media Server Messaging apps # Element Session Signal Tox Wire Mind-mapping # diagrams.net FreeMind Freeplane MindApps - Online TiddlyMap vym Office # Apache OpenOffice Caligra Cryptpad LibreOffice OnlyOffice PDF # Evince LibreOffice Draw Okular Sumatra Password Managers # Bitwarden KeepassXC Proton Pass Research Managers # JabRef Qiqqa Zotero Search engines # Brave DuckDuckGo MetaGer Qwant Searx Startpage YaCy To-do and notes # CherryTree Joplin OpenProject QOwnNotes Simplenote Standard Notes Zettlr Torrent Clients # qBittorrent Transmission UML # diagrams.net Modelio Papyrus UML PlantUML Umbrello VPN # Mozilla VPN Mullvad Private Internet Access Proton VPN RiseUp VPN Surfshark - Ref - NOS Windscribe I suggest checking out Techlore’s VPN Toolkit for more details on VPNs.
Video editors # Avidemux Kdenlive Olive OpenShot Shotcut Readers RSS # Feeder - Android Raven privacytools.io alternativeto.net restoreprivacy.com techlore.tech This list is under construction!
summary: This is a list of the best free and open source software alternatives for security and privacy.
title: Best Free and Open Source Alternatives (not all) for Privacy and Security

content:
Zotero + LibreOffice (Linux/Ubuntu based distros) - Credits to Kameid
Trying to solve the problem where the Zotero plugin doesn’t work properly in the Linux LibreOffice Writer:
Guide: # 1. Uninstall Zotero # 2. Make sure you have a Java Runtime Environment installed. # In LibreOffice, go to Tools>Options>Advanced. Make sure you have the “Use Java runtime environment” box checked, and if there is a JRE installed. If there isn’t one, open terminal and install the latest JRE:
sudo apt install openjdk-8-jre
3. Check if your installation worked. Run: # java -version
Output:
4. Restart LibreOffice # 5. install libreoffice-java-common: # sudo apt install libreoffice-java-common
6. Install Zotero # It should work fine now
Credits to Kameid
Zotero’s post about the troubleshooting process for the word processor plugin.
summary: Zotero + LibreOffice (Linux/Ubuntu based distros) - Credits to Kameid
title: Zotero + LibreOffice Integration (Linux/Ubuntu)
